large-group-materials.tg_materials-caption: Book: The Adventures of Jovani and Alejandro

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to build math background, engage children with an activity, and introduce vocabulary (adventures, harvests).
Start Story Time by introducing the book and asking, What do Jovani and Alejandro see on their trip?
Read for enjoyment, pausing to practice counting.
Check understanding, differentiating as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Understand that the order in which items are arranged or counted does not affect the total count.
Count aloud 1–10 items with one-to-one correspondence.
Manage emotions as needed (Self-Regulation).
Explore geography tools and resources, such as maps, signs, and street addresses

section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Mind Builder: Emotional Development; Executive Function

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Ask children to pick a certain number of “tomato” Connecting Cubes.
Guide children to harvest their Connecting Cubes in various orders by color.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: How can we be a good friend to others?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: How can you tell if the characters in this story are friends?
Pretend you and your friend are at a park. What will you do there?
How can you rearrange the number of cubes in that group? Is the total number still the same?
Can you write a story about an adventure you had with a friend?
What materials can you use to make two friends?
What letter makes the sound you hear at the beginning of the word friend? Can you write it?
What are two ways we can count the blocks you used? If we count from the bottom, are there the same number of blocks as when we count from the top?

large-group-materials.tg_materials-caption: Book: The Adventures of Jovani and Alejandro

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to share the Mind Builder manage emotions and introduce vocabulary (emotions, calm).
Begin Story Time by connecting the Mind Builder to The Adventures of Jovani and Alejandro.
Read closely to discuss how the main characters manage their emotions.
Offer an extended play opportunity.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Understand that the order in which items are arranged or counted does not affect the total count.
Count aloud 1–10 items with one-to-one correspondence.
Manage emotions as needed (Self-Regulation).
Identify emotions in self.
Identify emotions in others.
Contribute ideas and participate in group writing.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Ask children to create a cow using Pattern Blocks, and then count the blocks.
Invite children to correct your mistake as you count the blocks in a different order.
Model managing your emotions.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: How can we be a good friend to others?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: How does that character show they are a good friend?
Pretend you are going on an exciting trip. Show me how you feel!
Can you make two groups of four? What if you change the order? Are there still four?
Can you write about how you feel when you are with your friends?
Can you draw a person? How does the person feel? Can you change your picture to show a different emotion?
What letter sound do you hear at the beginning of calm? Can you write it?
Can you build a tower with these blocks? What if you made a bus with them instead? Would you have the same number of blocks?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. The Adventures of Jovani and Alejandro with photographs by Ted Hoffman. Copyright © 2021 by Scholastic Inc. Published by Scholastic Inc. Clifford the Big Red DogTM illustration copyright © The Norman Bridwell Trust.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

large-group-materials.tg_materials-caption: Book: The Adventures of Jovani and Alejandro

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to build math background, encourage children with movement, and introduce vocabulary (order, in all).
Begin Story Time by revisiting the book and asking the guiding question, How do Jovani and Alejandro use counting in their game?
Read interactively for deeper comprehension and to review counting.
Check understanding and differentiate as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Understand that the order in which items are arranged or counted does not affect the total count.
Count aloud 1–10 items with one-to-one correspondence.
Manage emotions as needed (Self-Regulation).
Identify emotions in self.
Identify emotions in others.
Convey meaning through marks, letters, or symbols.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Count Two-Color Counter horses “behind the curtain” and ask children to match the number.
Guide children to understand that the number of horses in each set is the same.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: How can we be a good friend to others?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: How do you think that character feels? Why do you think she feels that way?
How can you be a good friend to others when you play in this area?
How can you make these two groups the same number?
Write about why your best friend is a good friend to you.
How can you draw the same number of trees and apples?
How can you tell what letter is at the beginning of the word lamb? Can you draw it?
Why did you choose to build with those materials?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. The Adventures of Jovani and Alejandro with photographs by Ted Hoffman. Copyright © 2021 by Scholastic Inc. Published by Scholastic Inc.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

large-group-materials.tg_materials-caption: Big Chart of Big Ideas: Thank You, Friend!
Book:The Adventures of Jovani and Alejandro

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to reflect, sing a song, and introduce vocabulary (take turns, share).
Begin Story Time by connecting the texts Thank You, Friend! and The Adventures of Jovani and Alejandro.
Read interactively and connect to this week’s concept question, How can we be a good friend to others?
Offer an extended play opportunity.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Understand that the order in which items are arranged or counted does not affect the total count.
Count 1–10 items with one-to-one correspondence.
Manage emotions as needed (Self-Regulation).
Identify emotions in self.
Independently writes to communicate his/her ideas for a variety of purposes.

section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Mind Builders: Emotional Development; Executive Function

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Ask children to build a superhero using ten Connecting Cubes.
Count the cubes in each hero and guide children to understand that the number of cubes is the same regardless of counting order.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: How can we be a good friend to others?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: What do you think about that character?
Can you pretend to be the strongest superhero ever?
Can you put these groups in order from smallest to largest?
Write a story about a superhero who can count faster than anyone in the world!
What is your favorite part about what you have made?
What is the first letter of your name? Can you point to it?
Can you build a superhero? What material will you use first?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. The Adventures of Jovani and Alejandro with photographs by Ted Hoffman. Copyright © 2021 by Scholastic Inc. Published by Scholastic Inc.

large-group-materials.tg_materials-caption: Book: The Adventures of Jovani and Alejandro

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to play a counting game and introduce vocabulary (travel, close).
Start Story Time by revisiting the book and asking, How does having a friend make Jovani and Alejandro’s trip fun?
Read and reenact the story for physical engagement and imagination.
Check understanding, differentiating as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Understand that the order in which items are arranged or counted does not affect the total count.
Manage emotions as needed (Self-Regulation).
Identify emotions in self.
Identify emotions in others.
Distinguish words that sound similar but have different meanings.
Compose a narrative.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Support children as they independently respond to this week’s prompt: Write a number story about an activity you like do to with your friends.
Differentiate and modify as needed.
Save children’s writing to display next week.

section-block.tg_essential-question: How can we be a good friend to others?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Imagine this character were real. Do you think she would be a good friend for you to have?
Imagine having a pet. How could you be a good friend to your pet?
I see three cows. Imagine if this cow stood over here instead. Would there still be three in all?
Write about the best friend in the world.
Can you create a poster about all of your favorite things to do with your friends?
Can you trace the word friend in the sand?
Imagine you need a gift for a friend. What could you build for them?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. The Adventures of Jovani and Alejandro with photographs by Ted Hoffman. Copyright © 2021 by Scholastic Inc. Published by Scholastic Inc.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Count 1–10 items with one count per item.
Demonstrate understanding that when counting, the items can be chosen in any order.
Show ability to increase or decrease intensity of emotions more consistently, although adult guidance is sometimes necessary.
Explore geography tools and resources.
Count 1–10 items with one count per item.
Demonstrate understanding that when counting, the items can be chosen in any order.
Demonstrate an understanding that others have perspectives and feelings that are different from own.
Show ability to increase or decrease intensity of emotions more consistently, although adult guidance is sometimes necessary.
Begin to understand difference and connection between emotions/feelings and behaviors.
Discuss and contribute ideas for drafts composed in whole/small-group writing activities.
Count 1–10 items with one count per item.
Demonstrate understanding that when counting, the items can be chosen in any order.
Intentionally use marks, letters, or symbols to record language and verbally share meaning.
Begin to understand difference and connection between emotions/ feelings and behaviors.
Show ability to increase or decrease intensity of emotions more consistently, although adult guidance is sometimes necessary.
Demonstrate an understanding that others have perspectives and feelings that are different from own.
Count 1–10 items with one count per item.
Demonstrate understanding that when counting, the items can be chosen in any order.
Begin to understand difference and connection between emotions and behaviors.
Show ability to increase or decrease intensity of emotions more consistently, although adult guidance is sometimes necessary.
Independently write to communicate ideas for a variety of purposes.
Demonstrate understanding that when counting, the items can be chosen in any order.
Begin to understand difference and connection between emotions and behaviors.
Show ability to increase or decrease intensity of emotions more consistently, although adult guidance is sometimes necessary.
Demonstrate understanding that others have perspectives and feelings that are different from own.
Perceive differences between similar-sounding words.
Independently write to communicate ideas for a variety of purposes.
